description: Dive into "Cascais Captured: Picture-Perfect Moments" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Cascais Captured: Picture-Perfect Moments

places.generalDescription: Boca do Inferno, also known as Hells Mouth, is a stunning natural rock formation located just a 30-minute walk from Cascais. The site features eroded rock formations that have created impressive cavities where the sea water enters, producing a fearsome noise that gives the place its name. Visitors can witness this incredible natural event, especially on stormy days when the crashing waves create a powerful display.

sources.snippet: The coastline to the west of Cascais is defined by its dramatic cliffs shaped by the forces of the Atlantic Ocean ‚Äì and Boca do Inferno (Portuguese for Hell‚Äôs Mouth) might just be the most impressive formation of them all. The chasm and sea arch are formed from a collapsed cave and the waves relentlessly crash into the opening and explode upwards making it a popular tourist attraction. Fun fact: Boca do Inferno was the first cave to be depicted in a film.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To Do In Cascais, Portugal

sources.snippet: On the side of Cascais that faces the open ocean the coastline gets rocky, as you head into the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park. Only a short of walk from the marina is the Boca do Inferno (Hell‚Äôs Mouth), a chasm in the limestone cliffs. Try to be here where the surf is choppier to see the ocean surging through the hole in the bluffs and hear it echoing up the chamber.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Cascais (Portugal)

sources.snippet: Caves and rock formations shaped by the power of pounding waves has given this dramatic site the name of ‚ÄúMouth of (or the Gate to) Hell.‚Äù It‚Äôs a popular site for tourists, who take photos of the scenery to the sound of the awe-inspiring noise of the crashing waves. See the Boca do Inferno Guide.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Cascais Must-See Attractions and Things to Do

sources.snippet: Set a few minutes away from the town center, this astonishing cliff formation offers the best sea views in town. The cliffs form an open cave, and when the waves get rough, water splashes out everywhere. That‚Äôs why people call it Boca do Inferno, which means ‚ÄúHell‚Äôs Mouth‚Äù in Portuguese.
sources.shortName: The Perfect Cascais Day Trip: What to Do & Where to Eat
The best things to do in Cascais, Portugal

places.name: Boca do Inferno - Devil‚Äôs Mouth

reviews.text:
Very pretty and scenic area.
Wonderful natural rock formations and breathtaking views over the ocean side. Highly recommend the walk there from Caicais alas it is really pretty as well.
Obly downside is the rubbish that can be seen and found around the area, mostly fishing lines.
Overall a great experience and a sweet spot to visit/experience.

From all Lisbon and surroundings this was the most disappointing attraction for us. I mean don't get me wrong, it has its history and the water caves are nice to look at but I think you can spend your time visiting so many other better locations. Also when visiting Boca do Inferno you can barely breathe because there is a disgusting smell almost all over the place. I do not recommend this attraction!

If you have time while in Cascais, definitely check this out - impressive nature! There's also a public toilet (don't recommend it though üò¨) and a small cafe. We had some ice lollies and walked back to Cascais city centre (about 20 min walk).

places.address: Av. Rei Humberto II de It√°lia 642, 2750-642 Cascais, Portugal

places.generalDescription: Sintra-Cascais Natural Park is a stunning protected area that stretches from the lush mountains of Sintra to the beautiful Guincho beach and the dramatic cliffs of Roca cape, which is known as the westernmost point of Europe. This park boasts a diverse range of environments, including forests, sand dunes, lakes, and a rugged coastline with high cliffs and picturesque beaches. It's home to many rare species of flowers and animals.

sources.snippet: Located on the Portuguese Riviera, this 14,500ha (36,000 acres) park stretches from the mountains of Sintra to the coastline of Cascais and Cabo da Roca, continental Europe‚Äôs most westerly point. It encompasses both historical and natural wonders, from the hilltop Castelo dos Mouros (Castle of the Moors) to rugged cliffs, sandy bays, pristine forests and crystal clear lakes. The cliffside village in Azenhas do Mar and the collection of dinosaur trails and footprints in the South Cliff of Praia Grande are just two of the unmissable attractions to be found here.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To Do In Cascais, Portugal

sources.snippet: When you visit Cascais, you can‚Äôt miss the amazing Sintra-Cascais Natural Park (Parque Natural de Sintra-Cascais). One of Portugal‚Äôs 13 Natural Parks (protected areas for conservation ‚Äì similar to the US National Parks or UK Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty), this park covers 145km¬≤ and includes the Serra de Sintra Mountain Range and also extends to Cabo da Roca, which I mentioned previously.
sources.shortName: Top Things to Do in Cascais, Portugal

places.name: Parque Natural de Sintra-Cascais

reviews.text: Beautiful place , but unfortunately packed with tourists. Makes the whole experience of visiting stressful, especially if you go inside the castle, you cannot actually enjoy because people are in a line behind you. Going down we went thru the forest which was not easy, but with unexpected discoveries.

It's pretty cool seeing the outside although today there's construction on and it's definitely not as dramatic as seeing it 5 years ago. But you've come all the way to Sintra. See it. I skipped the interior this time. Not that great.
This was a great experience.  Our tour guide was so knowledgeable about the history.  We enjoyed it so much. It was beautiful ü§©!

places.generalDescription: Praia da Rainha, also known as Queens Beach, is a charming and intimate cove located in Cascais. Despite being one of the smallest beaches in the area, it boasts stunning golden sands surrounded by striking rock formations that overlook the Bay of Cascais. Its historical significance dates back to 1889 when it was a private retreat for Queen Amelia.

sources.snippet: Praia da Rainha might be one of the smallest beaches in Cascais but it packs a punch with golden sands surrounded by dramatic rock formations overlooking the Bay of Cascais. Praia da Rainha translates to Queen‚Äôs Beach, a reference to its former use as a private beach for Queen Am√©lia in 1889. The beachside Bar Praia da Rainha offers a selection of simple sandwiches, salads and drinks, while the Largo da Praia da Rainha square ‚Äì which overlooks the beach ‚Äì is home to the popular Music Bar Restaurante.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To Do In Cascais, Portugal

sources.snippet: Its name (‚ÄúQueen‚Äôs Beach‚Äù) recalls the time when it was the private beach of Queen Am√©lia in the 1880s, but it‚Äôs now accessible to everyone. It‚Äôs small but the perfect Instagram beach, hidden between rocks and cliffs, right in the pedestrianized center of town. The calm, crystal-clear waters attract families with children, young couples, standup paddleboarders, and teenagers who love to jump off the rocks.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Cascais Must-See Attractions and Things to Do

sources.snippet: This small postcard beach is hidden next to Praia da Concei√ß√£o, behind the mansion that‚Äôs now the Albatroz Hotel (see below). Its shallow waters are safe for children, while teenagers prefer to jump from the rocks on the western end. Its name (‚ÄúQueen‚Äôs Beach‚Äù) is a tribute to Queen Am√©lia, who used to spend the sunnier days here in the 1880s.

It isn‚Äôt easy picking a favourite beach in Cascais, because they all have their strong points. But if your vision of a perfect beach is a sandy cove lapped by crystalline seas then Praia da Rainha is the one for you. It‚Äôs also a few strides from Rua Frederico Arouca and so effortlessly close to bars and cafes.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Cascais (Portugal)

sources.snippet: Praia da Rainha, or Queens Beach, is a beautiful small beach in the old town, only accessible by foot through the many scenic alleys. If you are at Miradouro Fernandes, continue walking east through the buildings. Before you access the beach, you will discover another little viewpoint next to Praia da Rainha.
sources.siteName: S O N I A   D A V I E S
sources.shortName: Photographer‚Äôs Travel Guide to Cascais, Portugal ‚Äî S O N I A D A V I E S

sources.snippet: The Praia da Rainha is a small but picturesque beach right in the centre of Cascais. The beach is so pretty that in 1889 it was chosen by Queen Am√©lia as her private beach, and has been known as the Praia da Rainha (Queen's Beach) ever since. The pretty Praia da Rainha, as chosen by a queen...
sources.shortName: Cascais; the best sights, attractions and things to see and do in 2025

places.name: Praia da Rainha

reviews.text:
This beach was a very nice choice. Even if the beach is tiny and there were a lot of people, we still did some space for us. They have free bathrooms where you can also change to your swimming suit which is a big plus. It's a sandy beach so don't worry for rocks or anything else because you don't need beach shoes. The water was a little cold but little by little we managed in the end to get in and it was amazing. You will fond very nice tiny golfs where you can swim between the rocks.

I strongly recommend this beach!

The closest beach to the Cascais train station like 5 minutes on foot. It is quite crowded but i could always find a spot. I was hesitant to go far to the next beach but this is cleaner than the others so staying here was the great choice!

This is a beautiful beach with a lot of character! We loved how it was nestled in a cove-like area, with the rock formations surrounding you, plus it is right beside all of the beautiful, old streets - you only need to walk down some steps and you're on the beach. We'll definitely come back here!

WARNING: When swimming, be mindful of the rocks in the water! Double-check before diving in.

Only con: The water didn't seem the cleanest. There was heaps of random bits in it - I can't fully describe what all the stuff was. We still had a great time swimming, but it did feel a tad gross with different things floating about.

However, we'd happily visit again! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

ALSO! We HIGHLY recommend buying a pina colada from this stall on the street, before you go down the steps to the beach. You're served a whole pineapple with the tastiest pina colada freshly made in the pineapple. Once you have purchased a pineapple you can go back for refills for ‚Ç¨5 per pineapple drink. It was soo nice having this on the beach ü§åüèº

places.generalDescription: Casa das Hist√≥rias Paula Rego is a chic and upscale destination in Cascais, Portugal, offering a variety of attractions for visitors. The museum is dedicated to the late Paula Rego, one of Portugal's greatest contemporary artists. It houses a collection of her colorful and figurative artworks from the 1950s to the 1990s in bold pyramid-shaped towers inspired by the Palacio Nacional in Sintra.

sources.snippet: Paula Rego (1935-2022) is one of Portugal's most prominent modern artists, whose colourful artworks depicted sinister stories in a figurative style (a modern art style that retains strong references to the real world). The Casa das Hist√≥rias Paula Rego displays many of her finest pieces of work, housed in a distinctive building that was based upon the Pal√°cio Nacional in Sintra. The bold design of the Casa das Hist√≥rias Paula Rego, with the two towers that represent the National Palace in Sintra
sources.shortName: Cascais; the best sights, attractions and things to see and do in 2025

sources.snippet: A striking contemporary building displays the art of Paula Rego, one of Portugal‚Äôs greatest 20th-century artists. She was born in Lisbon and raised in Cascais, but achieved international acclaim in London. This museum exhibits dozens of her paintings and drawings, which were largely inspired by her childhood and controversial social realities.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Cascais Must-See Attractions and Things to Do

sources.snippet: Unmistakeable for its red pyramid-like towers, this art museum is dedicated to the Portuguese-British artist Dame Paula Rego. The building is from 2009 and was the work of Pritzker Prize-winner Eduardo Souto de Moura. It hosts temporary exhibitions of Rego‚Äôs paintings and graphic art, presented in a refreshingly frank and unpretentious way.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Cascais (Portugal)

places.name: Casa das Hist√≥rias Paula Rego

reviews.text:
This is a stunning piece of architecture housing a continuously changing exhibition of Paula Rego's varied work.
As an Anglo/Portuguese artist she her work is varied and shows empowering messages. From sculpture to theatrical costume with the illustration I can't recommend this museum enough.
The knowledge of the staff was incredible and I will revisit to build more knowledge of this amazing woman.

Highly divertive and mind-provoking exhibition, it was a well-used hour that I spended here. Even if the work of Paula Rego have some very dark topics and charisma, it's something you don't get to see somewhere else - unique work. And the building itself is of course marvellous!
It was short but sweet. The inside of the pyramid ceilings were awesome. It was a nice visit and the facilities were great. Worth the visit if you are in Cascais.

places.generalDescription: Casino Estoril is a sprawling and modern entertainment complex in Portugal, known for its gaming tables, slot machines, restaurants, and live shows. Situated in Estoril, it's just 18 kilometers from Lisbon and 20 kilometers from the International Airport. The casino has a rich history as a gathering place for spies and royals during World War II, inspiring Ian Fleming's James Bond novels. Its gardens extend to the train station and offer a pleasant setting for walks or bike rides.

sources.snippet: The flamboyant soirees and glamorous atmosphere of Casino Estoril is said to be the inspiration behind Ian Fleming‚Äôs Casino Royale, the first of the James Bond novels. It‚Äôs not only the largest entertainment complex in Portugal but is one of the world‚Äôs largest working casinos. Alongside the gaming rooms, you‚Äôll find a sprawling show and dining hall, an art gallery and an auditorium for performances ranging from jazz concerts to theatre.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To Do In Cascais, Portugal

sources.snippet: The Estoril Casino is one of the largest casinos in Europe and has long been a popular destination for the rich and famous. The casino offers a wide variety of traditional gambling games, such as roulette, blackjack and poker, as well as thousands of slot machines. The casino also hosts theatre performances and live music.
sources.shortName: Cascais; the best sights, attractions and things to see and do in 2025

sources.snippet: OK, so gambling might not be everyone‚Äôs cup of tea, but Casino Estoril needs to be seen, even if you‚Äôre only passing by. This first opened in 1916 and was reworked in the middle of the 20th century. It conjures images of jet set glamour, not least because Ian Fleming visited before writing Casino Royale.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to Do in Cascais (Portugal)

places.name: Casino Estoril

reviews.text: Just stop by when travelling from Cascais back to Lisbon. We wanted to see the famous casino from the outside. The park in front of it looks really amazing, we loved this short visit.

I had a fall in the Casino's car park. It was at night and there was no lighting. There are obstacles that should have been removed. Despite writing two emails to the addresses provided, I did not receive a response from the Casino with the information about the insurance policy, so the only option left for me is legal action.

This place is fabulous. Like walking back in time. I especially liked the added security at the door, where you show your identification and receive an entrance card to use in the future
Mandolin restaurant is great!
And I won enough on video poker to pay for it!

places.address: Av. Dr. Stanley Ho, 2765-190 Estoril, Portugal
